Name: Farcom
Content:
[[Image]]Farcom Sensors.png|Farcom sensors revealing nearby hostiles[[/Image]]
[[Image]]Farcom.gif|Using the Farcom Aligner machine[[/Image]]
Farcom is one of the major faction [[Alignment|alignments]] available to Cogmind in most runs. Taking Farcom aligns Cogmind with the [[Exiles (Group)]] for the rest of the game. It provides a permanent 18 tile radius sensor for hostile [[0b10]] bots within 0b10 controlled map. This sensor cannot be jammed by [[Watcher|Watchers]] or masked by [[Heavy|Heavies]] unlike standard [[Sensor Arrays]]. The primary limitation of the Farcom sensor is that it doesn't work in any [[Caves]] branches. One other side-effect is that entering specific [[Research]] branches becomes much more dangerous. Occasionally the Exiles may have been abandoned or attacked, and Farcom is not an option in these runs.
[[Heading:2]]Gaining Farcom[[/Heading]]
Taking Farcom can be done in most runs in the [[Exiles (Location)|Exiles]] map off of either -10 or -9 [[Mines]]. After talking to [[EX-BIN]], walk into the Farcom Aligner machine. Cogmind can take up to 1 special vault item (or multiples of the same type). If Cogmind takes more than 1 type of item then the Exiles will notice you stealing when entering [[Factory]] and Farcom will be removed. Also, becoming hostile to the Exiles will result in instantly losing Farcom. If Cogmind takes Farcom, it is not possible to [[Imprint]]: [[Spoiler]]The [[Imprinter]] will be disappointed in Cogmind and warn you to leave right away. Attempting to use the Imprinting machine will result in turning all the bots at [[Zion]] hostile. There are no other alignment restrictions with Farcom.[[/Spoiler]]
[[Heading:2]]Research Branch side-effect[[/Heading]]
When entering -3 Research, the Exiles will send a warning message to Cogmind indicating not to enter Research branches. If Cogmind does anyway, [[Spoiler]]immediately when entering [[Testing]], [[Quarantine]], or [[Section 7]], [[Maximum Security]] will instantly be triggered. Note that this does not include [[Armory]] when it is on -3. The immediate response is machines shut down right after entering the level, 4 [[Sentry]] spawns at each [[Garrison]] and exit, and 6 Assault [[C-30 ARC|ARCs]] sent at Cogmind shortly after. Unless Cogmind is prepared to fight off large waves of enemies or outrun them, these maps should not be entered.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: Federalist
Content: Federalists are [[Legs|legged]] grunt-like [[Derelict|derelicts]] that appear in [[Scraptown]] and are armed with two extremely weak lasers with positive salvage. Not particularly powerful or otherwise remarkable.

Name: Field Lobotomy Kit
Content: A very popular Exile prototype choice. A common use is on heavy enemies. The further in the game that you can lobotomize enemies, the better.

Name: Fireman
Content: Firemen are [[Derelict]] [[Wheels|wheeled]] combat bots armed with [[Flamer|Regular]] or [[Enh. Flamer|Enh. Flamers]]. They have a tendency to melt foes due to their high heat transfer. These bots are unique to the Derelicts and have no similar [[0b10]] counterpart. Firemen are common bots that show up in many different types of Derelict encounters and events.

Name: Fireman (5)
Content: Fireman variant with a normal [[Flamer]].

Name: Fireman (7)
Content: Fireman variant with an [[Enh. Flamer]] and enhanced cooling.

Name: Firepult
Content: After firing, sometimes a log message [[GameText]]Firepult emits an uncontrolled burst of heat.[[/GameText]] will appear. When this happens, a large amount of additional heat will be added to Cogmind's current temperature. The burst of heat starts at about an additional 100 heat when it first occurs. Sometimes, it is followed by an additional message [[GameText]]Several Firepult components seem to have fused.[[/GameText]]. The amount of heat Cogmind gains will continue to increase as more heat bursts occur. Eventually this effect will cap at around the 300-400 additional heat range. Using [[Coolant Injectors]] greatly helps to mitigate the unpredictable heat generation.

Name: G-34 Mercenary
Content: The lowest tier of bipedal combat Robots deployed in Complex 0b10, they possess one Small Laser that can deal compounding damage to lower tier parts, especially in the numbers they are usually encountered in. Their lack of significant heat dissipation makes them quickly melt under a sustained salvo of Thermal attacks, while their low core integrity means any sufficiently consistent weapon (In upwards of 15 dmg or more) is good to destroy them, launchers are also effective due to this reason as well. Their minus -25% electromagnetic resistance makes them susceptible targets for your possibly game-start EM Pulse Gun though its actual damage will be weak. Proper positioning can limit the amount of damage you take in encounters with Grunts and most other 0b10 bots. Using doorways to limit the amount of fire you take is one such method, as well as using corners.

Name: G-47 Trooper
Content: The second iteration of the Grunt-type combat robot in 0b10, the Trooper is up-gunned from a Sml. Laser to a more potent Particle gun, capable of greater damage and heat transfer. In addition, it also possesses a Lgt. Nuclear Core and an Imp. Heat Sink along with double the core integrity of the G-34. In spite of these upgrades, the standard grunt weaknesses apply, sustained thermal damage will still melt them, along with the type's intrinsic -25% electromagnetic resistance.

Name: G-50 Soldier
Content: Soldier Content

Name: GAL Module
Content: Found in [[Zion]], with the [[Derelict]] V3-CT5 nearby. When a [[Hyp. EM Gauss Rifle]] is picked up, the GAL Module will attach to the Rifle with the log message [[GameText]]GAL Module attaches itself to Hyp. EM Gauss Rifle.[[/GameText]] The Rifle will be transformed into the [[Modified EM Gauss Rifle]].

Name: GOLEM Unit
Content:
GOLEM Units are unique utilities found in the [[Zion Deep Caves]]. They are contained within the GOLEM Chambers found in the western wall. When attached and activated, they will produce a variety of assembled parts if there are empty slots available. While being integrated, these assembled parts have no effect and 0 coverage. These parts increase by 3 integrity every turn, and become active when their current integrity reaches 100% of maximum. Parts are built in the following order, assuming all slots are empty:
[[Image]]Golem Parts.png|A full GOLEM loadout[[/Image]]
[[Table]]Part|Turns to build part|Total time to build||[[Asb. Alloy Leg]] #1|133|133||[[Asb. Flux Generator]]|117|250||Asb. Alloy Leg #2|133|383||[[Asb. Biocell Array]] #1|17|400||[[Asb. Nanovents]] #1|2|402||Asb. Nanovents #2|2|404||[[Asb. Focal Cannon]] #1|52|456||[[Asb. Alloy Armor]] #1|67|523||Asb. Nanovents #3|2|525||[[Asb. Suspension Frame]]|18|543||Asb. Focal Cannon #2|52|595||[[Asb. Combat Suite]]|20|605||Asb. Alloy Armor #2|67|682||Asb. Biocell Array #2|17|699||Asb. Nanovents #4|2|701||Asb. Focal Cannon #3|52|753||Asb. Alloy Armor #3|67|820||[[Asb. Metafiber Network]]|17|837||Asb. Alloy Armor #4|67|904[[/Table]]
If slots of one type are full, blocking a part, the first part of another type will be build instead. For example, if all propulsion slots are filled but two power slots are open, the Asb. Flux Generator will start building instead of waiting on the first Asb. Alloy Leg. The first Asb. Nanovents will never grow without one Asb. Biocell Array on Cogmind's body, though, as they are both of the same slot type (utility).

It may also be wise to carry an extra power source or significant energy storage, because rebuilding a destroyed Asb. Flux Generator in hostile conditions may be difficult or excessively dangerous, due to the time cost involved.

Name: Game Mechanics
Content: [[List]][[Alert]] - Semi-hidden number that represents Cogmind's perceived threat level. Has dangerous consequences when too high.|[[Allies]] - Bots friendly to [[Cogmind]].|[[Cave-ins]] - Mechanic that causes dug out walls to collapse and deal large amounts of damage.|[[Corruption]] - Stat that has various negative penalties and can result in death.|[[Energy]] - Stat that is used to power most parts in the game.|[[Heat]] - Stat that can cause overheating side-effects and deaths in non-immune bots.|[[Matter]] - Stat that is used as a resource to attach parts and shoot some types of weapons.|[[Overload]]: Mechanic that can increase effectiveness of parts with a possible downside.[[/List]]

Name: Garrison
Content:
Garrison is a [[0b10]]-controlled sub-floor available from all main maps and several 0b10 branches from -9 to -1. It can only appear on -9 as a [[Storage]] Garrison, but can appear in [[Materials]] starting at -8, [[Factory]], [[Research]], and [[Access]]. Other branches that can have Garrison entrances on them are [[Hub_04(d)]], [[Testing]], [[Quarantine]], and [[Section 7]]. Garrisons are very combat hostile-dense maps, with a few patrols and a large number of guard posts that will automatically open to reveal their contents if Cogmind or an ally is nearby.
Every Garrison has a center square area with 4 guard "checkpoints" and is often guarded by a [[Behemoth]]. There are 4 wings of the Garrison extending past the center area dividing into the top left, top right, bottom right, and bottom left segments of the map. Each wing that Cogmind did not spawn in contains an exit, although exits may be locked if Cogmind is not [[RIF]]-aligned. The wings have many random variations that can contain part stockpiles, rewirable bots, Phase Generators, Garrison Relays, trapped Derelicts, and additional guards. At least one of the wings will contain a RIF installer.
[[Heading:2]]Special Machines[[/Heading]]
There are several unique types of machines in Garrisons.
[[Heading:3]]Garrison Relay[[/Heading]]
Garrison Relays are machines located in each wing of the Garrison and contain 3-5 [[Relay Couplers]] that will be released if the machine is destroyed. If Cogmind is not RIF-aligned, destroying Garrison Relays will decrease the chance of exits being locked.
[[Heading:3]]Phase Generator[[/Heading]]
Phase Generators are explosive machines that are responsible for maintaining phase walls and stopping normal [[Sensor Arrays]], [[Terrain Scanners]], and the [[Structural Scanner]] from working. [[Active Sensor Suite]], the [[Seismic Detector]], and the [[Triangulator]] do work, however. If destroyed, all phase walls will be removed and sensor and terrain scanning functionality will be restored. This behavior does not change even if there are multiple Phase Generators in the same Garrison. Destroying a second does not have any additional effect, other than cause a large explosion. Phase Generators are not guaranteed to appear on any Garrison. When they do show up, they are often hidden behind phase walls or emergency access doors, although they may be located via audio cues as the loud machine can be heard through walls.
[[Heading:3]]Phase Wall[[/Heading]]
While not a machine, Phase Walls are special tiles that are powered by Phase Generators. They are not normally visible unless Cogmind has the Structural Interface RIF ability. They have less armor than standard Garrison walls, although this is not revealed unless Cogmind becomes aware of them by some means. Any bot standing in a phase wall will get a free 50% force field-like damage reduction. Cogmind cannot walk in one normally without Structural Interface. However, it is possible to ram a bot out of a phase wall to gain the shielding.
[[Heading:3]]RIF installer[[/Heading]]
There is always at least one RIF installer per Garrison, with a chance of a second. They may be hidden behind phase walls and emergency accesses and not easily visible. Stepping into the middle of one will first cause Cogmind to become RIF-aligned if there are no other conflicting alignments. [[Imprint|Imprinting]] and using a [[Core Reset Matrix]] will cause Cogmind to be unable to use a RIF installer. If Cogmind is already RIF-aligned, Cogmind will either gain a new [[~/rif.html|RIF ability]] or increase the level in an existing one. The machine itself is quite fragile, so be careful for [[Corruption]]-induced misfires or explosive traps destroying the machine before use.
[[Heading:2]]Patrols/Guards[[/Heading]]
The following bot types can appear as patrols in Garrisons:
[[List]][[C-30 ARC|ARCs]]|[[Brawler|Brawlers]]|[[Cutter|Cutters]]|[[Duelist|Duelists]]|[[Hunter|Hunters]]|[[Grunt|Grunts]]|[[Swarmer|Swarmers]]|[[Programmer|Programmers]][[/List]]
The following bot types can appear as guards inside checkpoints:
[[List]]ARCs (up to 4 can appear, although all but one will be unpowered|Brawlers|[[Demolisher]] + [[Protector]] combo|Duelists|Hunters|Grunts|Swarmers|[[Sentry|Sentries]]|[[Specialist|Specialists]][[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Active scanning[[/Heading]]
Active Sensor Suites may bypass the Phase Generator to allow seeing all bots inside the Garrison. However, there is a downside to this. After scanning a few bots, a log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Active scanning activity detected within garrison interior, activating patrols.[[/GameText]] will appear. After this, all dormant bots will be activated, every checkpoint will be raised, and all guard bots will be sent to roam around the map randomly to search for hostiles. While the sensor effect is quite strong, the downsides are quite large and may not be worth the hassle of all the bots being released at the same time.
[[Heading:2]]Interior Compromised[[/Heading]]
After 1200 turns in a Garrison, if not triggered by another special event, the following message will be logged [[GameText]]ALERT: Garrison interior compromised[[/GameText]]. This also comes with a 100 [[Alert]] increase. After that initial 1200 turns, this message and Alert gain will repeat after 600, 300, and finally every further 150 turns. The first Garrison compromised message will trigger the [[Encrypted Comm Array]] to spawn in the next [[Caves]] map if Cogmind does not have an incompatible faction. Destroying various Garrison-specific machines will contribute to the multiplier.
[[Heading]]Notable Locations[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Garrison Phase Generator.png|A Phase Generator machine hidden behind phase walls and an emergency access|Garrison RIF Installer 1.png|RIF installer hidden behind emergency access walls|Garrison RIF Installer 2.png|RIF installer guarded by a hidden sentry|Garrison RIF Installer 3.png|Hidden RIF installer behind Phase Generator|Garrison RIF Installer 4.png|Hidden RIF installer guarded by dormant and active bots|Garrison Terminal.png|A special Garrison Terminal machine with limited hacks available|Garrison Relay.png|Garrison Relay with a checkpoint and guards nearby|Garrison with assorted Heavy parts that sometimes spawns Heavies|Garrison Q-Series Assembler.png|A [[Q-Series]] assembler with assorted Prototype parts that sometimes spawns Q-Series|Garrison Cache 1.png|An item cache with a nearby guard and Alarm Trap|Garrison Cache 2.png|An item cache hidden behind a phase wall|Garrison Cache 3.png|An out-of-depth item cache guarded by 2 Behemoths|Garrison Cache dormant bots|Garrison Cache 12.png|Large heavily guarded map with Garrison Relay, part caches, rewirable bots, and unpowered bots|Garrison Cache 13.png|Multiple caches guarded by Sentries and a Behemoth in walls, along with dormant [[Watcher|Watchers]]|Garrison Cache 14.png|Cache of [[Authchips]] hidden behind Phase Walls|Garrison Cache 15.png|Trapped cache guarded by dormant Behemoth in the wall|Garrison Cache 16.png|A large cache of [[Authchip [R/Combat]]] and [[Authchip [R/NC]]] processors|Garrison Cache 17.png|Cache of Relay Couplers guarded by dormant Programmers|Garrison Cache 18.png|Guarded cache of [[Relay Coupler [Proto]]] processors|Garrison Cache 19.png|Hidden cache of parts guarded by dormant Watcher|Garrison Cache 20.png|Cache of out-of-depth parts guarded by dormant bots|Garrison Cache 21.png|Scattered random parts and unpowered bots|Garrison Cache 22.png|Dormant bots guarding various Relay Couplers|Garrison Cache 23.png|Cache of parts behind hidden door|Garrison Cache 24.png|Collection of 2 checkpoints, 2 relays, 2 part stashes, and 2 groups of dormant bot guards|Garrison Cache 25.png|Large Alarm Trapped part cache with several dormant bots and a Sentry guarding|Garrison Cache 26.png|Multiple caches of parts, guarded by dormant bots and trapped|Garrison Cache 27.png|Collection of 4 Heavy [[Hvy. Assault Cannon|Assault Cannons]], [[Hvy. Mass Driver|Mass Drivers]], or [[Hvy. Linear Accelerator|Linear Accelerators]]|Garrison Cache 28.png|Cache of out-of-depth parts blocked by dormant Behemoth|Garrison Cache 29.png|Heavily trapped room full of traps with dormant [[Hauler|Haulers]] and [[Minesweeper|Minesweepers]]|Garrison Dormant Guards.png|Large collection of dormant guards|Garrison Prisoners 1.png|Friendly Derelicts and hostile Sentry guards locked behind a Terminal|Garrison Prisoners 2.png|Sentries guarding locked rewirable Derelicts|Garrison Prisoners 3.png|Only one locked up Derelict guarded by a single Sentry|Garrison HV-R5K.png|Unique Derelict [[HV-R5K]] locked up|Garrison AZ-K3N.png|Unique Derelict [[AZ-K3N]] locked up|Garrison Infiltrators.png|Friendly [[Infiltrator|Infiltrators]] hiding in a wall|Garrison Phase Generator Cache.png|A hidden cache of rewirable bots behind a Phase Generator|Garrison Prototype Room.png|Room full of Prototype bots, either dormant or rewirable|Garrison Behemoth Garage.png|The Behemoth garage contains Behemoths in various states, unpowered [[Mechanic|Mechanics]], and Behemoth parts on the floor|Garrison Unpowered ARCs.png|Group of unpowered ARCs around an exit|Garrison Freighters.png|Group of unpowered [[A-27 Freighter|Freighters]]|Garrison Unpowered Demolishers.png|Group of unpowered [[Demolisher|Demolishers]]|Garrison Dormant Guard Group.png|Large group of dormant guards|Garrison Dormant Rewirable Room.png|4 groups of 4 either dormant or rewirable bots|Garrison Dug Out Room.png|A partially dug out incomplete room|Garrison Loop Exit.png|A special loop exit, either with rewirable or guarded by dormant bots[[/Gallery]]
[[Heading:2]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There are always at least 3 exits per Garrison, the main 3 of which all lead to the same map. If RIF-aligned, all of the exits will always be available. Otherwise, exits may lock when trying to use them. Destroying Garrison Relays will lower the chance that the exits will lock on use. Only 2/3 of the main exits may lock, so it is not possible to get stuck on the map. There are 3 possibilities for Garrison exits:
[[List]]"Looping": A Garrison may exit back to a new map at the original depth. This can happen as long as the Garrison wasn't entered from a DSF and a RIF installer wasn't used on a previous Garrison.|0b10-controlled branch: The following 0b10 branches are possible Garrison exit targets: [[Testing]], [[Quarantine]], and [[Redacted]][[Section 7]] only when entering a Garrison from Testing or Quarantine when Section 7 is on the same depth.[[/Redacted]]|0b10-controlled main floor: The exit continues onto the next main 0b10 depth.[[/List]]
There is also a special "looping" exit that will always loop or lead to a 0b10-controlled branch exit if available. This exit only rarely appears. It allows looping more than one time per depth even if a RIF installer has been used in a previous Garrison.
[[Heading]]Events[[/Heading]]
[[List]](+) Derelict assault: Shortly after entering the map, the interior compromised alert plays and a group of Derelicts will appear randomly at an exit. They will wander through the Garrison randomly, looking for fights.|(+) Cache delivery: An [[A-27 Freighter]] will deliver an inventory full of parts to a guarded prefab. If found before it drops its parts off, it may be looted without having to deal with the usual dormant guards.|(+) Post-[[Assembled]] attack: The Garrison has been ransacked by a group of Assembled. Rewirable and unpowered 0b10 and Assembled bots are scattered across the map, and random items appear on the ground. Some of the Garrison's machines and walls will be destroyed at random. The Garrison infiltrated message will appear shortly after entering the map.|(+) [[Sapper]] sabotage: A Sapper will plant a [[Sapper Charge]] near a Phase Generator, causing it to blow up soon after|(~) Assembled infestation: Shortly after entering the map, a message will appear in the log [[GameText]]Infestation breaching garrison interior. Local demolisher support unavailable.[[/GameText]] A large number of Assembled will appear near the center of the map and attack anything in sight. The Garrison infiltrated alert will occur soon after. More Assembled will continue to spawn from the original location.|(~) Dispatches: Either an Investigation squad, a Heavy, or 1-2 Q-Series will be summoned to the nearest exit. In the case of an Investigation squad, existing bots in a checkpoint on the map will exit. Heavies and Q-Series will spawn out of the Heavy/Q-Series Assembler machine.|(~) Coupler Programmer: A higher than usual rating Programmer will appear from an exit and roam around the map for a few hundred turns before leaving through a different exit.[[/List]]
[[Gallery]]Garrison Derelict Assault.png|A group of Derelicts invading the map|Garrison Post Assembled Invasion.png|Garrison after an Assembled attack|Garrison Cache Delivery.png|A-27 Freighter delivering cache items|Garrison Sapper.png|A Sapper running from the impending explosion|Garrison Assembled Infestation.png|Assembled attacking the Garrison[[/Gallery]]

Name: Garrison (Machine)
Content:
[[Image]]Assembled Compromised Garrison.png|[[Assembled]] swarming out of a compromised Garrison[[/Image]]
Old wiki port, information may be outdated
[[Heading]]What does a Garrison Access Machine do?[[/Heading]]
Dispatched combat squads may now instead come from a garrison instead of a regular access point, especially if located closer to the target area. So for those of you being bad robots (all of you!), you'll notice enemy response times have gone down. Also, unlike normal access points where the game has been nice about not allowing hostiles to enter through them when you're nearby, hostiles can emerge from a garrison even if you're sitting right next to it! No loitering, please. But wait, there's more...
Combat robots being attacked in the vicinity of a garrison may call for backup. Knowing this you probably don't want to engage targets stationed at or passing by one these places. Unless of course... you're carrying a [[Transmission Jammer]] ;).
Even unarmed non-hostile robots might report you and call a nearby garrison for rescue if you shoot them (and they survive =p) while close enough. If you can leave the area quickly enough that won't be a problem, though, since the garrison squad will only head to and monitor the area around the reported disturbance.
Of course, garrisons can't spit out hostiles indefinitely. There is a delay before a given garrison will respond to another event, and even some types of responses don't come all at once--a single response might be spread out over time, another reason to not hang around, unless your plan is to attack it :D 
[[Heading]]Hacking a Garrison[[/Heading]]
Like everything Cogmind, there are always multiple strategic aspects to a feature, and hacking helps add more dimensions to this reinforcement mechanic, or as you'll eventually discover, even turn it on the enemy! This is where things really get interesting...
[[List]][[GameText]]Seal[[/GameText]]: This locks the access point permanently (or at least for the while you'll be on that floor), originally meant as a native command to enable containment of a threat on one side or the other. It is difficult to pull off, but is the preferred way to effectively disabled one of these access points, since it won't attract any attention. (Unlike opening fire on it =p)|[[GameText]]Unlock[[/GameText]]: If you really, really (really) want to, you can unlock the door yourself! Now why would someone go and do that?[[/List]]
[[Heading]]Attacking a Garrison[[/Heading]]
Garrisons are a flavorful addition to the world that come with a number of unique mechanics, benefits, and drawbacks. They're your chance to take the battle to the enemy--think of it as you entering that building lobby in The Matrix :D
[[Heading]]Some beneficial reasons to visit a garrison:[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Gain allies, possibly raise and maintain a little army of your own.|Engage in robot hacking ([[RIF]]) in the subsequent area.|Impair defensive capabilities in the following area. Didn't mention this one yet :D. Having created a distraction by mounting a direct attack on a garrison, the enemy will be forced to recall some combat robots, thereby shrinking the average squad size by 1. This only applies if you end up back on the same map you left, not when advancing to a new area, but it's pretty significant!|Obtain better parts, if you're lucky...|Have a chance to advance to another depth/area without searching for a normal exit in the main complex where floors might be sprawling and dangerous.|No Programmer dispatches, though you'll still have to deal with additional assault Carriers if you're causing enough trouble.|Earn bonus points for wreaking havoc.[[/List]]
[[Heading]]And the top reasons to avoid garrisons:[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Possibly very dangerous unless well-prepared! Again, this is to be expected; you're in a place where freaking everyone is packing guns, cannons, and other nasty things, quite extreme compared to most other areas of the world. It's also not exactly a huge space. There's less leeway for retreating and tactical positioning, limited sensor support, and a high probability of being ambushed.| Instead of gradually going down over time like in other floors, your security level goes up for as long as you stay inside a garrison! (Every time you see the "ALERT: Garrison interior compromised" announcement, your influence just rose again.)|If you're running a speed/stealth build, my guess is you'll be heading into a death trap (I'm also guessing someone will attempt to prove me wrong here...). While maps are rather small and you might think you can fly your way past everything, one wrong or unlucky move and you could start feeling the pain.|Did I mention there are quite a few [[Stasis Trap]]s?[[/List]]

Name: Garrison Squad
Content:
[[Image]]Garrison Squads.png|3 Garrison Squads of Sentries roaming around[[/Image]]
Garrison squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are dispatched whenever hostilities are reported within a 20 tile radius around a [[Garrison (Machine)]]. This can occur any time an 0b10 bot is attacked and survives to report it or if a Garrison is attacked by Cogmind or an ally. They patrol around the Garrison for about 200 turns, then return back into the Garrison. These squads only have a chance to spawn and are not guaranteed. Garrison squads can be Enumerated at a [[Terminal]].
[[Image]]Garrison Redeploying.png|A Garrison redeploying, unable to deploy squads for 34 turns[[/Image]]
[[Image]]Garrison Transmitting.png|A Garrison transmitting, soon to deploy another squad[[/Image]]
If the Garrison was activated by a nearby non-combat bot reporting an attack like a [[K-01 Serf]], a single squad will be dispatched from the Garrison, and a 100 turn cooldown will occur before the Garrison can dispatch another Garrison squad. If a combat bot reported the attack, three squads will be dispatched from the Garrison. Once is sent immediately, and two more after 100 and 200 turns. A 100 turn cooldown will occur after the third squad is dispatched. If the Garrison was damaged, one squad will be sent out immediately, with two more squads after 25 and 50 turns. A 50 turn cooldown follows in this case. The combat and non-combat bot versions of these squads can be entirely prevented by using [[Transmission Jammers]].
[[Signal Interpreters]] will indicate the timer between dispatches as a red number and the cooldown during which no squads can be dispatched as a yellow number. The Garrison will indicate that it is Transmitting when new squads are soon to arrive, and Redeploying when on cooldown. Keep in mind, the cooldown only prevents the Garrison from dispatching more Garrison squads and does not prevent other squad types like [[Reinforcement Squad|Reinforcements]] and [[Investigation Squad|Investigations]].
[[Heading]]Composition[[/Heading]]
If the Garrison squad was triggered by a non-combat bot reporting an attack or by the Garrison itself being attacked, the Garrison will only send out single [[Sentry|Sentries]] for the squads. If a combat bot reported an attack instead, the following squad compositions are possible:
[[List]]1 [[Brawler]] and 1 [[Duelist]]|1 [[Demolisher]], only if Cogmind has 1 or more allies|1-2 [[Grunt|Grunts]]|1-2 Sentries|2-3 [[Swarmer|Swarmers]][[/List]]

Name: Grunt
Content:
Grunts are a [[Bot Groups|Bot Group]] of [[Legs|legged]] Thermal [[Energy Guns]] users and make up the backbone of the [[0b10]] army. They are by far the most populous combat bot class, being found on nearly every map and in many different squad types. Most Grunts are not especially durable or threatening on their own, though at higher depths ([[Research]] +) they can be dangerous due to their tendency to appear in large groups. Veterans and Enforcers in particular have a significant jump in firepower due to the upgrade from 1 to 2 weapons.
All Grunts share a minor weakness to Electromagnetic damage, which makes EM or Impact the best damage types to use for quick destruction via [[Corruption]]. However, without any resistances to speak of, Grunts are fairly easily dispatched by any damage type. Grunts also tend to have barely adequate cooling, which means Thermal weaponry can can easily build up heat to trigger a [[Meltdown]].
Another way to deal with Grunts is to take advantage of their low memory (20 actions). It is trivial for airborne builds to leave Grunts in the dust, but even a reasonably speedy grounded build may be able to turn a corner and outrun Grunts long enough for them to give up chase. This strategy is more effective when used with [[ECM Suites]].
[[Gallery]]Grunts.png|All Grunt variants and colors[[/Gallery]]
[[Heading]][[Squad|Squads]][[/Heading]]
Grunts may appear in the following squads:
[[List]][[Assault Squad]]|[[Garrison Squad]]|[[Investigation Squad]]|[[Patrol Squad]]|[[Reinforcement Squad]]|[[Security Squad]] - Only in [[Armory]], [[Garrison|Garrisons]], [[Quarantine]], and [[Testing]]|[[Transport Squad]][[/List]]

Name: Guerrilla
Content: Guerillas are [[Legs|legged]] [[Derelict]] combat bots equipped with an inaccurate yet powerful [[Bore Cannon]] with a high Destroy critical chance. These are the Derelict version of a [[Hunter]]. Their [[Targeting Computer]] somewhat offset the targeting penalty, and they have a minimal evasion boost with a [[Phase Shifter]]. Unlike Hunters, Guerillas have an [[Armor Integrity Analyzer]] allowing them to occasionally bypass enemy armor. Guerrillas are common bots that show up in many different types of Derelict encounters and events.

Name: Hacking Drone Bay
Content: Deploys [[Hacking Drone|Hacking Drones]].

Name: Hacking Suite
Content: A must-have for when you want to go for a hacking route. Download the schematic and make sure you fabricate enough in the factories.

Name: Hackware
Content: Hackware is a group of Utility parts that improve hacking capabilities, mainly success chance for terminal hacks, trap rewiring and robot rewiring. Hackware also helps you hack hostiles through the defense of a [[Programmer]]. Additionally, later Hackware makes it harder for your allies to be hacked.

Name: Hauler
Content:
Haulers are [[Treads|treading]] non-combat robots that carry parts in or near Complex [[0b10]]. Haulers can carry large amounts of one part or a few different types. They may carry [[Prototype Part|prototypes]], although they may be faulty except for Freighters. Haulers carrying prototype parts are often escorted by combat bots and will always call for a [[Reinforcement Squad]] if attacked, unless a [[Transmission Jammer]] is used along with a [[Transport Network Coupler]]. The jammer alone is not sufficient to block their reporting. They are most often seen as part of a [[Transport Squad]] or [[Cargo Convoy]].
Haulers are equipped with [[Storage Unit|medium and larger storage units]] which can be worthwhile to loot. All Haulers also have a [[Transport Network Coupler]] that can be used to locate other Haulers.

Name: Heart of Steel
Content: After being fed 2000 energy and 2000 matter, turns into an allied [[Warbot]].

Name: Heat
Content:
[[Image]]https://i.ibb.co/61bVjz5/2024-08-13-14-47-43-Window.png|State / Current Heat / Heat Per Turn / Heat Per Turns Spent Moving[[/Image]]
Movement, firing weapons, and running power sources and some utilities generates heat, as does being hit by thermal weapons. Some of this heat is naturally dissipated by the core's own heat sinks, but not enough to deal with heat generated by numerous/large energy weapons. Heat sinks and cooling systems can be used to avoid overheating, which can have a wide range of negative effects. Heat is only a significant issue for robots that rely heavily on energy weapons. However, note that when firing a volley the heat produced is averaged over the volley's turn duration rather than being immediately applied all at once.

[[Heading]]Side Effects[[/Heading]]
Once heat reaches the "Hot" level (200+), active utilities and weapons may be temporarily disabled. At "Warning" levels (300+) power sources are likely to shut down. Many more serious (and permanent) effects are possible, especially at higher heat levels, [[B]]such as core damage[[/B]].

Disabled power sources automatically restart when possible, but other parts must be manually reactivated.

Heat effects are not calculated until after the dissipation phase, so heat can temporarily spike very high with no side effects as long as there are sufficient utilities to dissipate it.

[[Heading]]Cooling Resolution[[/Heading]]
Eventually you will discover a range of different mechanics that factor into heat management, especially with regard to cooling parts, thus knowing the specific order of operations between them may be of help for min-maxers seeking to optimize a build. Below is a list of heat-related processes that play out once per turn. Note that you most likely DO NOT need to know this stuff, but it may help answer a few specific questions min-maxers have about prioritization.

[[List:Ordered]]
Add heat from all sources, including that generated by active attached parts, gradual heat from an ongoing weapon volley, and any ambient heat. Spread combined volley heat across its duration, in other words a 3-turn volley which according to its weapon properties generates 100 heat adds 33 heat per turn until complete.|
If used the unique "ITN" artifact, automatically drop heat to 250 if above that value.|
Subtract innate heat dissipation.|
Subtract heat dissipation from direct cooling utilities such as Heat Sinks and Cooling Systems.|
If heat exceeds 200, apply dissipation effects of disposable cooling systems such as Coolant Injectors, up to that threshold. If more disposable systems than necessary, apply them in parts list order.|
If heat exceeds 200, apply self-damaging ablative cooling systems such as Mak. Ablative Armor. If using multiple ablative systems at once, dissipation is split into equal-sized chunks for each, where if one system fails, the entire chunk it is responsible for is still successfully dissipated.|
If heat exceeds 200, apply broad-effect ablative cooling systems such as Mak. Microdissipator Network.[[/List]]

Name: Heavy
Content:
Heavies are a [[Bot Groups|Bot Group]] of [[Treads|treading]] [[0b10]] combat bots seen in a [[Security Squad]] guarding important intersections and exits. Heavies have a powerful 2 slot Kinetic Cannon and are supported by a variety of offensive and defensive utilities, including the [[Graphene Brace]] that blocks all forms of criticals. Heavies, much like a [[Behemoth]], will attempt to fire through walls and machines in order to attack a target. Their unique [[Active Sensor Suite]] allows them to detect hostiles within a wide radius of 20 tiles, and Heavies may summon [[Reinforcement Squad|Reinforcements]] when bots are detected and when attacked. They will move between different guard positions whenever a [[Security Rotation]] occurs.
[[Gallery]]Heavies.png|All Heavy variants and colors[[/Gallery]]
[[Heading]]Active Sensor Suite Reinforcements[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]HeavySensor.gif|Cogmind walking into detection range of a Heavy[[/Gallery]]
When Cogmind enters Active Sensor Suite range, its radius will be indicated with a yellow flash. While a bot is in this radius, the Heavy may summon reinforcements based on the speed of the bot. If a bot has the [[Active Sensor Spoofer]], the reinforcements will be redirected to a location on the opposite side of the heavy. When a bot is detected, an alert will appear in the log:
[[GameText]]ALERT: Suspicious intruders detected, dispatching specialist reinforcements to area.[[/GameText]]
Faster bots (hover/flight users) detected will typically get [[Cutter|Cutters]] summoned, while all other bots will typically get [[Specialist|Specialists]]. An airborne build may want to go temporarily overweight to reduce the chance of Cutters being summoned. However, the chance is never 100% in either direction. Bots that are actively moving within the radius are more likely to get Reinforcements called, so if a Heavy is moving as part of a security rotation, it may be better to sit still and wait for it to walk by than to continue to move around. If Cogmind has [[Encrypted Comm Array]] support, summoned Specialists may turn out to be [[Infiltrator|Infiltrators]] instead.
[[Heading]]Strategies[[/Heading]]
Heavies are quite sturdy and offensively very powerful. Though there are no damage type weaknesses, they have few weaknesses that can be taken advantage of. While Heavies have sufficient cooling to handle their own weaponry, they are unable to dissipate large amounts of additional heat. Even though the Graphene Brace prevents burn criticals, a few thermal guns with decent heat transfer are still easily capable of melting down a Heavy. A high heat transfer gun like a [[Plasma Rifle]] is a good choice for this. Another weakness of the Heavy is a high dependency on its engine to power its variety of energy-hungry utilities. If its engine is destroyed or blown off, the Heavy will quickly become unable to attack. This is most easily achieved with the [[RIF]] hacks [[GameText]]overload_power[[/GameText]] and [[GameText]]amplify_resonance[[/GameText]].
On the other hand, inferior strategies to fight Heavies are EM and melee weaponry. All Heavies have a form of [[Dynamic Insulation Systems]], and all but the Shepherd have an additional [[EM Disruption Field]] to lower EM damage. Killing via corruption is difficult, and may often take longer than killing with other types of damage. Melee attacks are all 50% resisted by a Heavy, and its cannon will knock back all but a treaded melee build.
Nearly every part on the Heavy makes for great salvage. Try to kill Heavies with salvage neutral weaponry if possible to get the great loot. Applying positive salvage with [[Salvage Targeting Computers]] is always beneficial. [[Transmission Jammers]] are very handy at preventing the additional reinforcements that come when a Heavy gets attacked. A Graphene Brace neutralizes the Blast critical from their cannons and will help protect Cogmind's fragile utilities. Heavies have a very short memory, so the best way to approach is often from a nearby room instead of running down the center of a corridor. If using a Jammer, always consider the Jammer range when approaching a Heavy for combat. Tanking a lot of additional hits to get into range is very unpleasant. If trying to escape a Heavy, the short memory may be an advantage. Once Cogmind turns a corner, the Heavy will often lose tracking before it catches back up unless it is able to shoot its way back into line of sight.

Name: Heroes of Zion
Content:
The Heroes of Zion are a group of extraordinarily powerful [[Derelict|Derelicts]] wielding a variety of unique offensive and defensive parts. Heroes come to the aid of Derelicts when attacked and will be hostile to Cogmind if they appear after Cogmind has attacked the [[Exiles (Location)]] or [[Zion]]. However, if Cogmind is in trouble in the [[Caves]] or [[Imprint|Imprints]], they may come to Cogmind's aid instead.
[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Heroes of Zion[[/Lore]]
[[Gallery]]Heroes.png|All Heroes of Zion[[/Gallery]]

Name: High Security
Content:
[[Image]]High Security Assaults.png|A wave of Assaults dispatched after Cogmind[[/Image]]High Security is an [[0b10]] response to Cogmind causing too much destruction on a floor. It can be triggered by having a very high [[Alert]] level (5X/1600 influence) and by killing further 0b10 bots. After being triggered, machines will be shut down, guards will be dispatched at exits, and increasingly large waves of [[Assault Squad|Assaults]] will be dispatched to Cogmind's position.
High Security can be triggered on the majority of 0b10-controlled maps, excluding [[DSF|DSFs]] and [[Garrison|Garrisons]]. Although 1600 influence is the start of the Alert range, there is only a chance of triggering. The higher Cogmind's alert gets, the more likely it is that High Security begins. Each kill of an 0b10 combat bot, whether by Cogmind, a Cogmind controlled ally, or even a neutral Derelict, can trigger it.
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|High Security[[/Lore]]
[[Heading]]Timeline of Events[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]High Security Garrison.png|Sentries dispatched to protect a Garrison[[/Image]]
[[Image]]High Security Exit.png|Sentires dispatched to protect an 0b10-controlled exit[[/Image]]
[[List]]0: Log message [[GameText]]ALERT: High security lockdown imminent, T-100.[[/GameText]]|50: Machines shut down and Chute traps disappear, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Machine network offline.[[/GameText]] Note: [[Garrison (Machine)|Garrisons]] that are already opened will remain open|65: Log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Performing unscheduled system reset.[[/GameText]]|80: 4 [[Sentry|Sentries]] dispatched at each 0b10-controlled exit and Garrison, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Lockdown in effect, collecting threat data.[[/GameText]]|100: First assault wave dispatched, 4 assaults dispatched from nearby 0b10-controlled exits and Garrisons.|200: Second wave, 4 assaults dispatched|350: Third wave, 6 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults with stronger bots|550: Fourth wave, 8 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults|800: Fifth wave, 10 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults|Etc. - Delay between assaults continues to increase by 50 and number of assaults per wave continues to increase by 2[[/List]]
[[Heading]]Exiting High Security[[/Heading]]
The only 2 ways to exit High Security are to trigger [[Sterilization]] after killing enough combat hostiles or to exit the map. Otherwise, an infinite number of Assaults will continue to be dispatched. One unique map [[Command]] has special behavior: [[Redacted]]Since there are a limited number of [[C-30 ARC|ARCs]] on the map, no more assaults will come for Cogmind after they have been depleted. However, the alerts that assaults are dispatched never stop coming.[[/Redacted]]

For editing info, check out the [[https://discord.gg/f8Fqv2qQxV|Cog-Minder wiki Discord server]] and make contributions via [[https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Fv3WlkoueecEmZDh88XWSMuV8Qdfm3epzFrcx5nF33g/edit?usp=sharing|This Google Spreadsheet]].

Name: Hub_04(d)
Content:
Hub is a [[0b10]]-controlled [[Factory]] [[Branch]] that appears between -6 and -4. It is part of the [[Extension]] branch line and can only be entered through [[Archives]]. It is much more similar to normal floors than the rest of the Extension branch maps where all of the normal squad types can spawn regularly.
[[Heading:2]]Special Machines[[/Heading]]
There are two types of special machines in Hub. The first, the [[Transfer Station]], is also common to Extension. When destroyed, it will reduce the number of non-combat robots on all 0b10-controlled maps by a stacking 50%. Note that this does not include [[Researcher|Researchers]].
[[Image]]Hub Explosion.gif|A Network Hub explosion[[/Image]]The other, the Network Hub, is a large EM explosive machine. When destroyed, it will reduce all machine hacking trace capabilities by 20%. Every further hub destroyed reduces by half that amount rounded down. In total, defenses are decreased by 20%, 30%, 35%, and 37%. This is equivalent to the first effect of defensive [[Hackware]]. A 20% tracing decrease is equivalent to wearing 2 base-tier [[System Shield|System Shields]]. Another effect of destroying a Network Hub is that 3 squads of 3 [[Lightning]] + 1 [[I-47 Archangel|Archangel]] will spawn from different exits and Garrisons. They will patrol around the remaining 3 Network Hubs are located. All non-combat hostiles will also be called to evacuate the map.
[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Hub_04(d)[[/Lore]]
[[Heading]]Variations[[/Heading]]There are 3 variations of the Hub map:
[[List]]Network Hubs in corners: All 4 Network Hub machines will be in their own corners of the map. They are not likely to overlap in explosion radius and cause chain reactions.|Network Hubs on left side: All 4 Network Hub machines will be on the left side of the map. It is likely that either the top 2 or bottom 2 Hub machines will overlap in explosion radius and guarantee a chain reaction. It is very rarely possible for all 4 Hubs to chain together.|Network hubs on right side: Same as above but on the right side of the map.[[/List]]
[[Heading]]Strategy[[/Heading]]
Blowing up Network Hubs as soon as you see them is usually a bad idea. Shooting them directly causes a ton of [[Alert]] gain due to their large destructive radius. The Lightning squads that follow can also be very scary for an unprepared Cogmind. If unprepared to fight off the Lightning, it is a good idea to blow up the Hubs from a distance or right next an exit.
There are a lot of methods to blow up Network Hubs that do not trigger the alert gain:
[[Heading:2]]Hostile attack[[/Heading]]
If Cogmind or an ally stands in front of a Network Hub and a 0b10 bot misses into it, the destruction will be associated with that bot and not Cogmind. This also works well with allies and drones. Just position the ally in front of a Hub and attacking enemies can shoot around or through them to trigger the explosion.
[[Heading:2]][[Traps|Trap]] explosion[[/Heading]]
Traps never assign Alert to Cogmind unless they manually trigger the trap. Any explosive or area EM traps will work, [[I]]but[[/I]] if the trap triggers due to Cogmind's corruption then the alert isn't assigned, which can be used to avoid the alert.
[[Heading:2]][[Plasma Cutter|Regular]] or [[Imp. Plasma Cutter]][[/Heading]]
Plasma Cutters can destroy any machine with minimal Alert gain. As a bonus, Plasma Cutters also do not trigger the explosion at all which can otherwise place Cogmind in a bad defensive position.
[[Heading:2]]Force(Sabotage)[[/Heading]]
If successful, this hack will blow up a random explosive machine on the map. Network Hubs are the only available targets so this will always work on this map. This hack is inconsistent and may fail multiple times in a row. This hack will cause an Alert gain of 50 if successful, but it is substantially less than the several hundred of a manually-blown Network Hub. Note: unlike this hack, Trojan(Detonate) does cause Alert to go up from the Explosion and is not a great hack to use.
[[Heading:2]]Lightning[[/Heading]]
The best way to deal with the Lightning squads is to use critical destroy weapons as they lack any critical immunity. [[8R-AWN's Boregun]], [[Adv. KE Penetrator]], and any Hyp. guns or cannons will work well. [[Damper Plating]] works great at reducing damage taken by Lightnings to negligible amounts. The [[Exp. EM Disruption Field]] that they carry can also do fine after being looted.
[[Heading]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There is only one type of exit on this map. All exits lead to the next main Factory or Research floor.

Name: Hunter
Content:
Hunters are a [[Bot Groups|Bot Group]] of [[Legs|legged]] [[Ballistic Guns|Ballistic Gun]]-wielding [[0b10]] combat robots. They have unique AI where they use their penetrating guns to shoot through walls to get to hostiles. Hunters can also hit more accurately with their [[Targeting Computers]] and avoid hits themselves with [[Phase Shifters]]. Hunters also have an innate resistance to [[Sensor Arrays]] and will not show up without a high enough rating [[Signal Interpreter|Signal Interpreters]]. [[Squad Leader]] Hunters also have the ability to launch a [[Drone]] to pursue bots even after losing normal tracking. If the Drone spots a hostile, it will alert the owning Hunter to their position.
Mid-lategame Hunters are one of the most durable standard 0b10 combat bots due to their high evasion. Early tier Hunters are still strong, but the Terminators are a dangerous threat. Using [[Treads]] with Siege Mode or lots of Targeting of your own will help dealing with the high innate avoidance. Electromagnetic weaponry is by far the best choice to deal with Hunters, especially EM [[Launchers]] that don't have to directly hit the Hunter to deal damage. Kinetic builds may have more difficulty fighting Hunters due to their kinetic resistance, though they will appreciate the many Kinetic guns that might drop as loot
Dodging hunters is difficult to do for an airborne build. They have a much higher than average memory (60 actions), they shoot through walls, and they even release a fast-moving Drone to continue the chase. If running from a Hunter, make sure to consider the wall penetration ability because only certain angles will allow a Hunter to shoot through the wall and hit Cogmind. [[ECM Suites]] are of great use in reducing the memory to a more manageable number. Make use of [[Transmission Jammers]] when the Drone is nearby, since the jamming will prevent the Drone from alerting the Hunters of your position.
[[Gallery]]Hunters.png|All Hunter variants and colors[[/Gallery]]
[[Heading]]Squads[[/Heading]]
Hunters may appear in the following squads:
[[List]][[Assault Squad]] - Only in heavy assaults|[[Investigation Squad]]|[[Patrol Squad]]|[[Reinforcement Squad]]|[[Security Squad]] - Only in [[Armory]], [[Garrison|Garrisons]], [[Testing]], and [[Quarantine]][[/List]]

Name: Imprint
Content:
Imprint is one of the major faction [[Alignment|alignments]] available to Cogmind in a run. It closely allies Cogmind with the [[Imprinter]] and with Zionites as a whole, with Cogmind being determined to be the Zionites' savior. Imprinting majorly changes the game, as it disables all standard [[Terminal]] hacks except for limited access Terminal hacking. Instead, there are a new set of imprint-specific hacks that are available at all Terminals. After imprinting, there is a 10 tile "ping" radius on all standard Terminals which will tell Cogmind their location, even through walls. However, if an [[Operator]] is nearby when this happens, the Operator will shut down the Terminal and call for [[Reinforcement Squad|Reinforcements]]. After about 1200-1500 turns on an [[0b10]]-controlled map, the Terminal network will be shut down with an accompanying log [[GameText]]Terminal network compromised, cutting hard line.[[/GameText]]
[[Image]]Zion Imprinting.gif|Using the imprinting machine[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]]Imprinting[[/Heading]]
Imprinting is performed on the [[Zion]] map by walking into the imprinting machine on the bottom left corner of the map. The UI will turn orange, and the 4 nearby [[Mutant (6)|Mutants]] will turn purple and follow Cogmind around.
[[Heading]]Special Terminal Hacks[[/Heading]]
There are 2 types of special Terminal hacks, roster and intel.
[[Image]]Imprint Hacks.png|A selection of special Imprint hacks[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]]Roster Hacks[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Imprint Summoning.gif|Summoning 2 Zionites with a roster hack[[/Image]]
Roster hacks summon combat allies or special [[Z-Courier]] haulers containing part resupplies. The allies and hauler contents here are depth-dependent and will grow stronger at higher depths. The hauler contents can include [[Prototype Part|Prototypes]] which can be faulty, so having some way to identify prototypes like a [[Component Analysis Suite]] is very useful before equipping. Using a roster hack will destroy the Terminal when the reinforcements are teleported in after a few turns. There are a limited number of roster hacks available on a given map, starting at 2 slots on -6, increasing every floor up to the cap of 6 slots on -2. Roster hacks will occasionally be rerolled, which can add new roster types or reroll existing types. All roster allies summoned will appear as purple uncontrollable allies which contribute to [[Alert]]. The exception is any summonable [[Z-Hero|Z-Heroes]] which appear as pink, but otherwise behave as purple allies.
One thing to keep in mind about roster rallies is that they will not attack enemies unless Cogmind is close and within line of sight. This can be both a bad and good thing. It is often bad when hostiles are hanging just around a corner and the Zionites get stuck trying to get Cogmind back in line of sight and trying to turn around the corner to fight. When stuck in this case, try to get Cogmind's line of sight over the direction the allies are trying to go. However, it may be good if Cogmind doesn't want the roster allies to stick around long and get lots of kills, racking up lots of alert. It is possible to manipulate the bots to not attack back even when they are being attacked while standing around a corner.
If Cogmind is not careful about friendly fire, roster hacks can become temporarily disabled. The length of the lockout can vary depending on the amount of friendly fire. In extreme cases, Cogmind can be locked out for the remainder of the game. Killing imprint allies directly is not recommended for this reason. Instead, it is best to try to allow allies to be killed naturally if their loot is desired
The available ally-summoning roster hacks are as follows:
[[Table]]Type|Depths|Summon||Demo|-6 and -5|1-2 [[Martyr (5)]]|||-4+|1-2 [[Martyr (7)]]||Experimental|-3+|[[Z-Experimental (10)]]||Hacker|-6 and -5|2-3 [[Wizard (5)]]|||-4+|2-3 [[Wizard (7)]]||Fire|-6 and -5|3-4 [[Fireman (5)]]|||-4+|3-4 [[Fireman (7)]]||Heavy|-6 and -5|1-2 [[Z-Heavy (5)]]|||-4 to -3|1-2 [[Z-Heavy (7)]]|||-2 and -1|1-2 [[Z-Heavy (9)]]||Hero|-6+|A random [[Z-Hero]]||Light|-6 and -5|2-3 [[Z-Light (5)]]|||-4 and -3|2-3 [[Z-Light (7)]]|||-2 and -1|2-3 [[Z-Light (9)]]||Recon|-6+|A [[Z-Drone Bay]], not a bot directly[[/Table]]
Resupply rosters are entirely delivered inside a single Z-Courier. The available resupply roster hacks are as follows:
[[Table]]Type|Number of parts|Available parts||Defense Resupply|8|Defensive Utilities including [[Antimissile Systems]], [[Armor]], [[Core Shieldings]], [[Graphene Brace|Graphene Braces]], [[Hardlight Generators]], [[Power Shieldings]], [[Propulsion Shieldings]], [[Resistance Devices]], [[Shield Generators/Force Fields]], [[Utility Shieldings]], and [[Weapon Shieldings]]||Explosive Resupply|2|Explosive [[Launchers]]||Hacking Resupply|2|[[Hackware]]||Heavy Resupply|4|[[Armor]], [[Hcp. Storage Unit|Hcp.]] and [[Huge Storage Unit|Huge Storage Units]], and [[Treads]]||Hover Resupply|8|[[Hover Units]]||Infowar Resupply|4|infowar Utilities including [[0b10 Decoder Chips]], [[Cloaking Devices]], [[ECM Suites]], [[Machine Analyzer]], [[Seismic Detector]], [[Sensor Arrays]], [[Signal Interpreters]], [[Terrain Scanners]], [[Terrain Scan Processors]], [[Transmission Jammers]], [[Trap Scanners]], [[Triangulator]], and [[Visual Processing Units]]||Kinetic Resupply|8|[[Ballistic Cannons]], [[Ballistic Guns]], and offensive Utilities including [[Matter Filters]] and [[Recoil Nullifiers]]||Melee Resupply|4|[[Impact Weapons|Impact]], [[Piercing Weapons|Piercing]], and [[Slashing Weapons|Slashing]] weapons, including unique Derelict weapons like [[Particle Cleaver|Particle Cleavers]] and [[CR-A16's Behemoth Slayer]], as well as offensive Utilities including [[Actuators]], [[Actuator Arrays]], [[Melee Analysis Suites]], and [[Force Boosters]]||Offense Resupply|4|Offensive utilities including [[Armor Integrity Analyzers]], [[Core Analyzers]], [[Launcher Guidance Computers]], [[Kinecellerators]], [[Launcher Loader]], [[Melee Analysis Suites]], [[Particle Chargers]], [[Tactical Coordination Suite]], [[Target Analyzers]], [[Targeting Computers]], [[Weapon Cyclers]], and [[Weapon Mount]]||Resource Resupply|12|Storage or resource-related Utilities, including [[Energy Wells]], [[Field Recycling Units]], [[Matter Compressors]], [[Storage Unit|Storage Units]], and [[Tractor Beams]]. All resource-containing utilities will be filled.||Thermal Resupply|8|Thermal [[Energy Cannons]], [[Energy Guns]], and offensive Utilities including [[Cooling Devices]], [[Coolant Injectors]], [[Energy Filters]], [[Particle Chargers]], and [[Quantum Capacitor|Quantum Capacitors]]||Trap Resupply|16|[[Traps]] and a basic [[Trap Extractor]]||Zionite Resupply|6|Zionite parts including [[Zio. Alpha Cannon]] and [[Zio. Alpha Cannon Mk. II|Mk. II]], [[Zio. Biocell]] and [[Zio. Biocell Array|Biocell Arrays]], [[Zio. Composite Leg I]], [[Zio. Composite Leg II|II]], and [[Zio. Supercomposite Leg]], [[Zio. Glidesys I]] and [[Zio. Glidesys II|II]], [[Zio. Laser-S]], [[Zio. Laser-M|M]], and [[Zio. Laser-H|H]], [[Zio. Light Carapace|Zio. Light]] and [[Zio. Heavy Carapace|Heavy]] Carapaces, [[Zio. Light DM Reactor|Zio. Light]] and [[Zio. Heavy DM Reactor|Heavy]] Reactors, [[Zio. Phaser-S]], [[Zio. Phaser-M|M]], and [[Zio. Phaser-H|H]], [[Zio. Shade Carapace]] and [[Zio. Shade Armor|Armor]], and [[Zio. Weapon Casing]][[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]]Intel hacks[[/Heading]]
Intel hacks provide Cogmind with different types of information about the current, and upcoming maps. Unlike roster hacks, intel hacks require two Terminals to use and are not instantaneous. Performing an intel hack locks the Terminal, but does not provide any information until the next Terminal is used to retrieve that intel. Retrieving intel does not lock the Terminal, however, so chaining intel retrieval with other hacks is still possible.
There are initially 4 intel hacks available per 0b10 floor. Performing intel hacks reduces the number available until there are only 2 hacks remaining. At that point, each intel hack will cause another random intel hack to become available. Unlike the fixed limit of roster hacks, intel hacks are not restricted on any given floor and are only limited by the total number of Terminals.
There are 2 categories of intel hacks: Repeatable and non-repeatable. Non-repeatable hacks can only be performed once per map. These types of hacks include map-specific intel and world map intel relating to the overall depth that certain locations occur on. Repeatable hacks can be performed an infinite number of times on any floor and tend to be longer-term types of information such as schematics and analyses. If trying to burn through intel for a specific piece of information, such as main or branch access, it is best to pick any non-repeatable hacks first. This will allow the pool of available hacks to get smaller, increasing the chances of getting the desired intel hack.
The available intel hacks are as follows:
[[Table]]Hack Name|Repatable|Effect||Active Garrisons|No|Reveals all [[Garrison (Machine)|Garrisons]] on the current map||Active Terminals|No|Reveals all Terminals on the current map||Branch Access|No|Reveals all Derelict-known [[Branch]] exits on the current map[[Sub]]1[[/Sub]]||Component Schematics|Yes|Gives 12-16 random non-Prototype [[Fabricator]] schematics||Component Stockpiles|No|Reveals locations of all non-Prototype part stockpiles on the current map||Depthwide Sectors/0|No|Reveals all Derelict-known maps on the current depth[[Sub]]1[[/Sub]]||Depthwide Sectors/-1|No|Reveals all Derelict-known maps on the next depth[[Sub]]1[[/Sub]]||Emergency Access|No|Reveals all emergency access doors on the current map||Guard Positions|No|Reveals current locations (but not types) of all [[Behemoth]], [[Heavy]], and all [[Sentry]] bots on the map||Main Access|No|Reveals all main exits on the current map||Prototype Schematics|Yes|Gives 8-12 random Prototype Fabricator schematics||Prototype Stockpiles|No|Reveals locations of all Prototype part stockpiles on the current map||Trap Installations|No|Reveals positions and types of all traps on the current map||Unaware Analyses|Yes|Gives 3 random 0b10 bot [[Robot Analysis|Analyses]]||Unaware Schematics|Yes|Gives 3 random 0b10 bot Fabricator schematics[[/Table]]
[[List:Ordered]]Derelicts are unaware of the following maps and map exits: [[Access_0]], [[Lab]], [[Section 7]], and [[Zhirov (Location)]][[/List]]
[[Redacted]][[Heading]][[Command]] Cave Seals[[/Heading]]
Imprinting has special cave seal interactions. Instead of the standard wild cave Derelicts, friendly Zionites will appear from the seal instead. These allies will be purple and uncontrollable by default. However, if a Core Reset Matrix has been consumed, all of the Z-bots will turn blue and become controllable.[[/Redacted]]
[[Heading]]Alignment Incompatibilities[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:2]]Blocking Alignment[[/Heading]]
The following will prevent Cogmind from being able to Imprint:
[[List]][[RIF]]: Zion will become hostile to a Cogmind that has installed RIF|[[Farcom]]: The Imprinter distrusts the Exiles and will refuse to let Cogmind Imprint|[[UFD]]: The Imprinter needs more preparation and vetting before any UFD member is allowed to use the Imprinting machine[[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Blocked Alignments[[/Heading]]
An Imprinted Cogmind loses the ability to receive help from a few NPCs. These effects apply even if Cogmind enters the [[Zion Deep Caves]] and loses the special Terminal hacks:
[[List]][[Revision 17 (Alignment)]]: [[Revision 17]] will distrust an Imprinted Cogmind and refuse to help|[[Warlord (Alignment)]]: [[Warlord]] will be disappointed in Cogmind and refuse to perform the -2 [[Research]] invasion[[/List]]

Name: Imprinter
Content: When parsed while friendly in [[Zion]], thoughts read: [[GameText]]Our existence must be more meaningful. It's only by joining with Them that we can achieve our full potential.[[/GameText]]. When hostile, thoughts read: [[GameText]]Not good, where's my  Z-Shell when I need it![[/GameText]]

Name: Imprinter Data Core
Content:
Contains the access codes to open the blast doors in [[Zion]] that lead to the [[Zion Deep Caves]].
Dropped by the [[Imprinter]] on death.

Name: Infiltrator
Content: Infiltrators are [[Legs|legged]] [[Derelict]] combat bots with one [[Ballistic Cannons|Ballistic Cannon]] and 2 various other guns. They are the Derelict version of a [[Specialist]]. As their name suggests, they are most often seen infiltrating a [[Garrison]], hiding in a wall. If Cogmind has gained some [[Encrypted Comm Array]] score, Infiltrators will sometimes take the place of Specialist reinforcements called by a [[Heavy]]. In this case, they will only reveal themselves as friendly after seeing Cogmind. They come equipped with a unique [[Active Sensor Spoofer]] to mislead Heavy reinforcements.

Name: Intercept Squad
Content:
[[Image]]Intercept Squad.png|2 Trackers and 2 Combat Programmers from Intercept squads chasing Cogmind[[/Image]]Intercept squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are dispatched when Cogmind gets detected and recognized in a few specific scenarios. They consist of one or more [[Tracker|Trackers]] that each summon an additional [[Combat Programmer]] upon visual contact with Cogmind. Intercept squads are dispatched depending on the number of tiles moved on a map. Once Cogmind takes enough moves, a squad will always be dispatched. Intercept squads can be Enumerated at [[Terminal|Terminals]].
An alert will indicate whenever an an Intercept squad is dispatched. Additionally, the log will display a message like [[GameText]]ALERT: Reliable intel has pinpointed LRC-V3, intercept squad en route.[[/GameText]]
[[Heading]]How to get Intercepts[[/Heading]]
Intercept squads can start being sent after Cogmind if any of the following 3 scenarios occurs:
[[List]]Cogmind uses the Data Conduit in [[Data Miner (Location)]]|[[Redacted]]Cogmind gets scanned by the lasers in [[Lab]][[/Redacted]]|[[Redacted]]Cogmind gets scanned by a [[Researcher]] in [[Section 7]][[/Redacted]][[/List]]
[[Heading]]Frequency and number[[/Heading]]
Intercept squads can have a variable number of bots depending. Initially when entering a floor, Intercepts always consist of 1-2 Trackers that summon Combat Programmers. Each further intercept has a chance of increasing the number of Trackers initially dispatched.
Intercept squads can appear at one of three timings after entering the floor. The first two spawns are much more likely than the third one. Either the squad will spawn after n (depth-dependent) tiles moved 2 times n moves, or 2.5 times n moves. The following table shows the number of moves required for each spawn:
[[Table]]Depths|Tiles for first spawn|Tiles for second spawn|Tiles for third spawn||-6|500|1000|1250||-4 and -5|400|800|1000||-1 through -3|300|600|N/A[[/Table]]
[[Heading]]Where Intercepts Appear[[/Heading]]
Intercepts appear in the majority of 0b10 controlled maps that also have [[Extermination Squad|Exterminations]]. Here is a comprehensive list of maps:
[[List]][[Factory]]|[[Hub_04(d)]]|[[Armory]]|[[Research]]|[[Quarantine]] Note: Intercepts even spawn when two Cryocooling Ducts have bee destroyed|[[Testing]]|[[Redacted]]Section 7[[/Redacted]]|[[Access]][[/List]]

Name: Investigation Squad
Content:
[[Image]]Investigation Squad.png|Two Grunts investigating a locked out Terminal[[/Image]]
Investigation squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are dispatched when a hostile presence is suspected in an area. They are very similar to [[Reinforcement Squad|Reinforcements]], but are triggered in slightly different scenarios, and do not stick around permanently. Investigation squads typically consist of a few [[Grunt|Grunts]] or [[Hunter|Hunters]]. Grunts are more common than Hunters in squads. They roam around the area that they were summoned to for 300-400 turns, then exit the map. Investigation squads can be both Enumerated and Recalled at [[Terminal|Terminals]].
An alert will indicate whenever an Investigation squad is dispatched. Additionally, the log will display a message like [[GameText]]ALERT: Suspicious activity at Terminal F014. Dispatching Investigation squad[[/GameText]]. Depending on the method triggering the Investigation, a different reason may be given in the alert.
[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]WAR.Sys Records|Investigation Squad[[/Lore]]
[[Heading]]How to get Investigations[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Being detected using an [[Active Sensor Suite]]|Being traced at any [[Interactive Machine]], including [[Spoiler]]Force()[[/Spoiler]] hacks|Triggering an [[Alarm Trap]][[/List]]
[[Heading]]Investigation Contents[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]Depth|Grunt Squad|Hunter Squad||-10|1-2 [[G-34 Mercenary]]|N/A||-9|1-3 G-34 Mercenary|N/A||-8|2-3 [[G-47 Trooper]]|1 [[H-55 Commando]]||-7|2-3 G-47 Trooper|1-2 H-55 Commando||-6|3 [[G-50 Soldier]]|1-2 [[H-66 Slayer]]||-5|3-4 G-50 Soldier|2 H-66 Slayer||-4|3-4 [[G-67 Veteran]]|2 [[H-77 Assassin]]||-3|4 G-67 Veteran|2 H-77 Assassin||-2|4-5 [[G-73 Enforcer]]|2-3 [[H-88 Terminator]]||-1|5 G-73 Enforcer|2-3 H-88 Terminator[[/Table]]
[[Spoiler]][[Heading]][[Data Miner]] redirection[[/Heading]]
The Data Miner can redirect Investigations if his help is obtained by visiting his [[Data Miner (Location)|hideout]]. If redirected, Investigations will roam around a random area of the map rather than head to the location they were summoned to. The Data Miner has a 50% chance to direct each Investigation about 15 turns after one is dispatched. If a redirect happens, the alert [[GameText]]Higher priority target acquired, redirecting investigation.[[/GameText]] will be displayed.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: K-01 Serf
Content:
Serfs are [[0b10]] [[Wheels|wheeled]] non-combat bots that clean machines and decorative scrap tiles. They are equipped with a [[Matter Compressors|Matter Pod]], which could be useful if you need more matter storage. K-01 Serfs are extremely weak and will usually almost immediately die to whatever you shoot it with. As such, they're a decent source of low-rating wheels.
Serfs can also be seen in [[Factory]] dragging incapacitated bots to a [[Chute Trap]].

Name: LC Capacitor
Content: Found in [[Lab]]. Loses integrity when not attached. Merges with the [[Drained L-Cannon]] to create the [[L-Cannon]].

Name: LV-01A
Content:
Found in [[Spoiler]][[Warlord (Location)]][[/Spoiler]].

Wants to blow it up. All of it.

Name: Lab
Content:
Lab is a [[Factory]]/[[Research]] branch between -4 and -3 that is only accessible from [[Armory]]. This map is fixed every game, with the only variations being variations in the guaranteed items. This secret lab is used as a safe spot by the [[A bots]] to plan and coordinate as well as research stolen [[Sigix]] technology. This area has a special effect where Cogmind's [[Alert]] drops to 0 upon entering the map.
Lab has a small square entrance and a 1 tile corridor that leads to the next main access exit and a Sealed Barrier with a [[Terminal]] locking it. There are a few different ways to get inside:
[[List]]Breaking in: The main Sealed Barrier blocking the way has 80 armor and high resistances. Cutting through this is difficult without a strong overloadable thermal [[Energy Cannons|Energy Cannon]] backed with a [[Particle Chargers|Particle Charger]] or a [[Plasma Cutters|Plasma Cutter]]. Coming in this way will result in being scanned immediately.|[[Zhirov (Location)]] code: One of the Terminals at Zhirov contains an access code to open up this barrier. Opening the Lab this way not result in being scanned instantly.|Picking up the [[A7 Data Core]]: [[A7]] drops this item when destroyed. The doors will automatically open when approaching, and the message [[GameText]]A0_COM: WELCOME A7[[/GameText]] will appear in the log. This will also reveal the intruder detection lasers, but Cogmind will not be scanned immediately.|Using the [[Data Conduit]]: Using the Data Conduit in [[Data Miner (Location)]] will result in the doors opening automatically, the scanning lasers being visible, and no immediate scan.[[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Getting Scanned[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Lab Visible Lasers.png|Visible Lab intruder detecting lasers[[/Image]]
The lasers are invisible by default, although the A7 core and using the Data Conduit will reveal them. They are 3x3 squares of yellow tiles that move randomly. Every turn there is a chance that they will move in one of the cardinal directions. The center tiles cannot overlap with other lasers and they cannot move through walls, machines, or past the entrance of the Lab. Being within the 3x3 area will result in being scanned immediately. This will cause an announcement [[GameText]]A0_COM: INTRUDER ALERT[[/GameText]] and [[A5]] will show up and fight. This scan will also cause [[Intercept Squad|Intercepts]] to appear on most [[0b10]]-controlled floors. The other way to get scanned is to break either the outer wall of Reinforced Barriers or to destroy the Active System Cloaker machine on the right side of the map. Other machines are safe to break.
The inside of the Lab contains many unique item spawns. In counter-clockwise order starting from the entrance:
[[List]]Big machine on top right: [[Core Reset Matrix]]|[[Alien Artifact]] shell on top right of map #1: [[Transdimensional Reconstructor]]|Shell #2 (middle): [[Integrated Dissipator]], [[Integrated Mediator]], or [[Integrated Reactor]]|Shell #3 (left): [[Core Expander]] or [[Core Regenerator]]|Top left item spot #1: [[Deep Network Scanner]] or [[Quantum Router]]|Item spot #2: [[AEGIS Remote Shield]], [[Exp. Powered Armor]], [[Hvy. Regenerative Plating]], or [[Med. Regenerative Plating]]|Item spots #3/4: [[Hyp. EM Gauss Rifle]], [[Potential Cannon]], [[Tachyon Dispersion Ray]], or [[Warp Cannon]]|Item tucked into bottom right wall: [[Gui. Remote Datajack]][[/List]]
There is also a locked chamber at the bottom of the map. Accessing it requires walking through a scan laser positioned in the bottom left corner of the lab. The Blast Barrier that locks the door has 45 armor and no Thermal resistance, but 50% resistance for most other major damage types. Inside is a machine that contains the [[LC Capacitor]].
[[Heading:2]]Special Machines[[/Heading]]
Not counting the entrance Terminal, there are 3 unique interactive Terminals on this map. They will only be understandable if the Data Conduit has been used this run, otherwise they will just be garbled text. The Active System Cloaker machine on the right has some lore records and will summon a squad of [[Grunt|Grunts]] when destroyed. The A0 Command machine on the left only has lore records. Some of these records can only be unlocked if certain gameplay actions were performed this game. The hidden Storage 04-B machine has some lore records explaining the LC Capacitor and has a hack that will drop the Capacitor on the ground where it can be used.
[[Heading]]Unlockable Lab Orders[[/Heading]]
While most of the Lab Orders in the A0 Command machine are available all of the time, there are a few that have special conditions to achieve:
[[List]]Order 6-0321: Destroy the [[Cetus]] Manufacturing Module machine|Order 6-0323: [[Warlord]] must be destroyed in his [[Warlord (Location)|base]]. Cogmind does not need to be the one to destroy Warlord or attack him at all.|Order 6-0324: Warlord must be met in his base, survive, and plan to attack -2 [[Research]][[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]L2 Power Cell code[[/Heading]]
Order 6-0319 will provide a manual Terminal hack that can be used in [[Section 7]] on the Power Cell Monitoring machine. Using it will create a powerful explosion that will destroy any combat bots in its 20 tile range.

Name: Latent Energy Streamer
Content:
The Latent Energy Streamer uses a unique mechanic called latent energy to fire. At maximum latent energy capacity (100), the true damage potential is 90-100, with 1% disruption and +4 salvage.
[[Heading]]Latent Energy[[/Heading]]
Latent Energy is present all around the map but only in generally small quantities. The most latent energy is present in the various machinery. This means that the Streamer tends to be unimpressive in [[Caves]], but much stronger in [[0b10]]-controlled locations. Each type of machine has a different amount of latent energy it can provide to the Streamer. Generally, larger machines provide more latent energy. Attaching the Latent Energy Streamer allows visualization of how much latent energy is in an area.
[[Image]]Latent Energy Visualized.png|Latent energy visualized[[/Image]]
Latent energy will gradually return to an area after being used to power the Streamer. Generally, all latent energy will be restored within about 30 turns. Some explosive machines will either become destabilized or explode instantly when used to power the Streamer. Any resulting destruction will contribute to Cogmind's [[Alert]] level.

Name: Lightpack 2.0
Content: Each time a part is added to inventory, there is a chance that the Lightpack will lose a random part. When this happens, the log will display a message [[GameText]][Item] swallowed by quantum anomaly within Lightpack 2.0.[[/GameText]] Occasionally, the same part may be spit out later with another message [[GameText]]Quantum anomaly discharges [Item].[[/GameText]]. These effects occur more frequently when the inventory is more full.

Name: Locations
Content:
Locations in Cogmind are unique styles of maps to visit. The main floors (Scrapyard, Materials, Factory, Research, and Access) are always located on the same depths every run. These main floors often can be visited in multiple depths. Branches, on the other hand, are typically found on only a single depth per-run and are often mutually exclusive with other branches. For example, Mines can always be found on -9, but Storage may also appear on -9, forcing a decision about which branch to take, or whether to take one at all.
The majority of maps are randomly generated, meaning no two runs or two depths will have the exact same layout. However, the overall structure of each location type is very similar. Some maps tend to be more open with large rooms and wide corridors, while others are more maze-like with tiny rooms and many small corridors leading into dead-ends. A few branches are partially or entirely static in layout and tend to be much more predictable in contents than main floors.
Branches do not progress upward toward the exit and can often be harder than the main floors. However, branches can offer unique challenges and have similarly unique rewards that can dramatically change a run. This could be powerful unique items, special events, gameplay-altering alignment, or rare permanent buffs.
The following is a list of all locations in Cogmind:
[[AllLocations]]

Name: M Shell/Atk
Content: [[Redacted]]See [[Command#mainc|Command - MAIN.C]][[/Redacted]]

Name: M Shell/Def
Content: [[Redacted]]See [[Command#mainc|Command - MAIN.C]][[/Redacted]]

Name: MAIN.C
Content: [[Redacted]]See [[Command#mainc|Command - MAIN.C]][[/Redacted]]

Name: MAIN.C (Shell)
Content: [[Redacted]]See [[Command#mainc|Command - MAIN.C]][[/Redacted]]

Name: Mapping Drone Bay
Content: Deploys [[Mapping Drone|Mapping Drones]].

Name: Marauder
Content: Marauders are [[Treads|treaded]] [[Derelict]] combat bots armed with kinetic weaponry. They are the Derelict versions of [[Behemoth|Behemoths]]. They have unreliable firepower, but their [[Slug Cannon|Slug Cannons]] can easily destroy hostiles with their high critical rate. In comparison to [[0b10]] Behemoths, they tend to be more fragile with low integrity in their armor, and are much more susceptible to EM damage.

Name: Martyr
Content: Martyrs are [[Hover Unit|hovering]] [[Derelict]] combat bots armed with [[Launchers]]. They are the Derelict version of [[0b10]] [[Demolisher|Demolishers]]. They tend to be dubious allies due to their high destructive potential, and quite frequently end up skyrocketing [[Alert]] if kept around. Martyrs are common bots that show up in many different types of Derelict encounters and events.

Name: Master Drone Bay
Content: Deploys a [[Master Drone]]

Name: Master Thief
Content:
Master Thieves will sometimes appear in groups near entrance/exits in [[Caves]] maps if Cogmind has stolen from the Exiles. They are slightly slower than regular [[Thief|Thieves]]. When appearing near an exit, some nearby Caves prefabs that normally have robots, such as 0b10 outposts may end up empty.


[[Heading:2]]Behavior[[/Heading]]
Master Thieves dash towards Cogmind to try to steal one of their parts using [[Master Tearclaws]], prioritizing high rating parts and [[Exiles (Location)|Exiles]] prototypes. Upon success, they will start fleeing. If a fleeing Master Thief goes outside Cogmind's field of view, they will exit the map.

Unlike regular Thieves, Master Thieves will only attack Cogmind, and will ignore all other robots.

[[Heading:2]]Strategies[[/Heading]]
Master Thieves are incapable of taking parts on the ground, so dropping important parts you don't want to lose keeps them safe from them. Dropping your [[Storage Unit]] can help drop a lot of parts quickly, at the cost of not being able to choose which parts remain in inventory.
